Sub_topics.description: WS 1.1 Understand how scientific methods and theories develop over time: describe how methods/theories change; explain why new experimental/observational data can change models; decide whether given data supports a theory. WS 1.2 Use models (representational, spatial, descriptive, computational, mathematical) to solve problems, make predictions and develop explanations: recognise/draw/interpret diagrams; translate data into models; use models to explain data and match model features to observations; calculate/predict using models and identify limitations; suggest how to test models. WS 1.3 Appreciate power/limitations of science and consider ethical issues: explain why data is needed and why it can be uncertain/incomplete/unavailable; outline simple ethical arguments about new technologies. WS 1.4 Explain everyday/technological applications; evaluate personal/social/economic/environmental implications; make decisions based on evidence/arguments: describe/explain applications; evaluate methods (with data) tackling human impacts. WS 1.5 Evaluate risks in practical science and wider societal contexts, including perception of risk vs measured risk (eg voluntary vs imposed, familiar vs unfamiliar, visible vs invisible hazards); weigh hazards and benefits. WS 1.6 Recognise importance of peer review and communicating results to varied audiences: explain peer review’s role in detecting false claims/establishing consensus; recognise media reports are not peer reviewed and may be oversimplified/inaccurate/biased.

WS 2.1 Use scientific theories/explanations to develop hypotheses. WS 2.2 Plan experiments/devise procedures for observations, producing/characterising substances, testing hypotheses, checking data, exploring phenomena: describe/justify procedures; explain need to manipulate/control variables; identify independent variable (changed/selected), dependent variable (measured), control variables (kept same) and why. WS 2.3 Select appropriate techniques/instruments/apparatus/materials and justify choices. WS 2.4 Carry out experiments appropriately: correct manipulation, measurement accuracy, health and safety; identify hazards and suggest risk reduction. WS 2.5 Apply sampling techniques so samples are representative. WS 2.6 Make and record observations/measurements; read scales and record appropriately. WS 2.7 Evaluate methods: sufficient/precise measurements; validity; suggest improvements and further investigations.

WS 3.1 Present observations/data appropriately: construct/interpret frequency tables/diagrams, bar charts, histograms; plot two variables. WS 3.2 Translate data between graphical and numeric forms. WS 3.3 Carry out mathematical/statistical analysis: significant figures; mean and range; frequency representations; order-of-magnitude; change subject; substitute into equations with units; slope/intercept of linear graph; tangent gradient for rate; physical meaning of area under curve and estimate by counting squares. WS 3.4 Describe uncertainty: every measurement has uncertainty; use range about mean as uncertainty measure; estimate uncertainty and represent distributions. WS 3.5 Interpret data in verbal/diagrammatic/graphical/symbolic/numerical forms; identify patterns/trends; make inferences; draw conclusions; make predictions. WS 3.6 Present reasoned explanations; relate data to hypotheses; judge consistency; choose best hypothesis. WS 3.7 Objectively evaluate data: accuracy (close to true), precision (clustered), repeatability (same method/conditions/investigator), reproducibility (different investigators/equipment), random error (unpredictable; reduce by repeats/mean), systematic error (consistent offset), handle anomalies. WS 3.8 Communicate rationale, methods, findings, conclusions via written/electronic reports using verbal/diagrammatic/graphical/numerical/symbolic forms.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Scientific vocabulary, quantities, units and symbols (WS 4)
Sub_topics.description: WS 4.1 Use scientific vocabulary/terminology/definitions. WS 4.2 Recognise importance of scientific quantities and how determined. WS 4.3 Use SI units (eg kg, g, mg; km, m, mm; kJ, J) and IUPAC nomenclature unless inappropriate. WS 4.4 Use prefixes and powers of ten (tera, giga, mega, kilo, centi, milli, micro, nano) for orders of magnitude. WS 4.5 Interconvert units. WS 4.6 Use appropriate significant figures. Applies across the whole specification including required practicals.

Compare plant/animal (eukaryotic) cells: cell membrane, cytoplasm, genetic material enclosed in nucleus; with bacterial (prokaryotic) cells: much smaller; cytoplasm, cell membrane, cell wall; genetic material not in nucleus as a single DNA loop; may have plasmids (small rings of DNA). Understand scale/size of cells; perform order of magnitude calculations using standard form; use prefixes centi-, milli-, micro-, nano-.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Animal and plant cell organelles and functions
Sub_topics.description: Relate sub-cellular structures to function: nucleus, cytoplasm, cell membrane, mitochondria, ribosomes; plus in plants: chloroplasts, permanent vacuole (cell sap), cellulose cell wall; in bacteria: plasmids. Recognise/draw/interpret images of cells. Use estimations to judge relative size/area of sub-cellular structures. Required practical 1: light microscope observation of plant and animal cells; draw and label; include magnification scale (use microscope, measure length/area).

Explain (with given information) how structure of specialised cells relates to function at tissue/organ/organ system/whole organism level. Examples: sperm cells, nerve cells, muscle cells (animals); root hair cells, xylem and phloem cells (plants).

Explain importance of cell differentiation: as organisms develop, cells differentiate into different types; most animal cells differentiate early; many plant cells retain ability to differentiate throughout life. In mature animals, cell division mainly for repair/replacement. Differentiation involves acquiring different sub-cellular structures, becoming specialised.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Microscopy (light vs electron) and magnification maths
Sub_topics.description: Understand how microscopy developed over time; explain electron microscopy increases understanding of sub-cellular structures; differences limited to magnification and resolution (electron microscope higher magnification and resolving power). Calculate magnification, real size and image size using: magnification = size of image / size of real object; express in standard form where appropriate; use prefixes centi-, milli-, micro-, nano-.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Chromosomes, DNA and genes (cell division context)
Sub_topics.description: Nucleus contains chromosomes made of DNA molecules; each chromosome carries many genes; in body cells chromosomes normally in pairs. Use models/analogies to explain cell division.

Describe stages of the cell cycle including mitosis (no need for named mitotic phases): cell grows and increases sub-cellular structures; DNA replicates forming two copies of each chromosome; in mitosis one set of chromosomes pulled to each end and nucleus divides; cytoplasm and membranes divide producing two genetically identical cells. Explain importance in growth and development of multicellular organisms; recognise contexts where mitosis occurs.

Define stem cell as undifferentiated cell capable of producing more cells of same type and differentiating into other cells. Describe functions in embryos, adult animals (eg bone marrow → blood cells) and plant meristems (can form any plant cell throughout life). Understand potential uses (eg diabetes, paralysis), therapeutic cloning (embryo with same genes as patient; reduced rejection), and risks/ethical or religious objections (eg viral transfer). Plant meristem stem cells for rapid economical cloning: conserve rare species; clone disease-resistant crops. Knowledge of stem cell techniques not required beyond described uses/risks.

Explain diffusion across cell membranes: net movement from higher to lower concentration in solutions or gases; examples include O2/CO2 exchange and urea diffusion from cells to plasma for excretion. Explain factors affecting diffusion rate: concentration gradient, temperature, membrane surface area. Explain significance of surface area:volume ratio for unicellular organisms and why multicellular organisms need exchange surfaces/transport systems; adaptations of small intestine, lungs (mammals), gills (fish), roots/leaves (plants): large surface area, thin membrane/short diffusion path, efficient blood supply (animals), ventilation for gas exchange. Calculate and compare surface area:volume ratios; use models/diagrams for diffusion.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Osmosis in cells (plant tissue required practical)
Sub_topics.description: Define osmosis as diffusion of water from dilute to concentrated solution through a partially permeable membrane. Use diagrams/models of osmosis. Use simple compound measures of rate of water uptake; use percentages; calculate percentage gain/loss of mass of plant tissue; plot/draw/interpret graphs. Required practical 2: effect of salt/sugar concentration on mass of plant tissue (record mass/time; calculate % change; graph).

Explain active transport as movement from more dilute to more concentrated solution (against concentration gradient) requiring energy from respiration. Applications: mineral ion uptake by root hairs from dilute soil solution; glucose absorption in gut into blood. Describe transport into/out of cells by diffusion, osmosis and active transport; explain differences between the three processes.

Explain hierarchical organisation: cells are basic building blocks; tissues are groups of similar cells with similar structure/function; organs are aggregations of tissues with specific functions; organ systems are groups of organs working together to form organisms. Relate to size/scale across levels.

Digestive system as organ system for digestion and absorption. Enzymes: protein molecules with specific active site; catalyse specific reactions; lock-and-key model as simplified explanation; relate activity to temperature and pH; perform rate calculations. Recall sites of production and actions of amylase (starch → sugars), proteases (proteins → amino acids), lipases (lipids → glycerol + fatty acids). Bile: made in liver, stored in gall bladder; alkaline to neutralise stomach HCl; emulsifies fats into droplets increasing surface area; increases lipase rate. Products of digestion used to build carbohydrates, lipids, proteins; glucose used in respiration. Required practical 3: qualitative food tests (Benedict’s for sugars, iodine for starch, Biuret for protein, plus test for lipids as required by practical wording). Required practical 4: effect of pH on amylase rate using continuous sampling (iodine test every 30 s), control temperature with water bath/heater, measure time to digest starch.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Heart, blood vessels and gas exchange structures
Sub_topics.description: Describe structure/function of human heart and lungs and lung adaptations for gas exchange. Double circulatory system: right ventricle → lungs; left ventricle → body. Blood vessels named: aorta, vena cava, pulmonary artery, pulmonary vein, coronary arteries (valve names not required). Lungs structures: trachea, bronchi, alveoli, capillary network around alveoli. Natural pacemaker in right atrium; artificial pacemakers as electrical devices to correct irregular heart rate. Blood vessels types: arteries, veins, capillaries; explain structure-function; use compound measures/rate calculations for blood flow.

Blood as tissue: plasma with red blood cells, white blood cells and platelets suspended. Know functions of each component; recognise different blood cells in photographs/diagrams and explain adaptations. Consider risks related to use of blood products.

Explain coronary heart disease: fatty material builds in coronary arteries narrowing them, reducing blood flow and oxygen to heart muscle. Treatments: stents to keep arteries open; statins reduce cholesterol and slow deposit. Faulty valves: may not open fully or may leak; understand consequences; replacement with biological or mechanical valves. Heart failure: transplants (heart or heart-lung); artificial hearts used temporarily or to rest heart. Evaluate advantages/disadvantages of drug, mechanical device or transplant treatments; weigh benefits/risks.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Health and disease interactions; interpreting incidence data
Sub_topics.description: Define health as state of physical and mental well-being. Communicable and non-communicable diseases cause ill health; factors such as diet, stress, life situations affect health. Disease interactions: immune defects increase infection risk; viruses can trigger cancers; immune reactions can trigger allergies (rashes, asthma); severe physical ill health can cause depression/mental illness. Translate disease incidence between graph/numeric forms; construct/interpret frequency tables/diagrams, bar charts, histograms; use scatter graphs for correlation; understand sampling principles in scientific and epidemiological data.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Lifestyle factors and non-communicable disease risk
Sub_topics.description: Discuss human/financial cost of non-communicable diseases at individual/community/national/global levels. Explain how lifestyle factors (diet, alcohol, smoking; exercise) affect incidence at different scales. Define risk factors; some have proven causal mechanisms, others not. Required mechanisms/examples: diet/smoking/exercise and cardiovascular disease; obesity and Type 2 diabetes; alcohol effects on liver and brain; smoking effects on lung disease and lung cancer; smoking/alcohol effects on unborn babies; carcinogens including ionising radiation as cancer risk factors. Interpret data, sampling and correlations about risk factors; extract/interpret charts/graphs/tables.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cancer (benign vs malignant) and risk factors
Sub_topics.description: Describe cancer as changes in cells causing uncontrolled growth/division. Benign tumours: contained, do not invade/spread. Malignant tumours: invade tissues, spread in blood to form secondary tumours. Identify lifestyle and genetic risk factors for cancers (high-level description).

Explain how plant tissue structures relate to functions: epidermal tissues, palisade mesophyll, spongy mesophyll, xylem, phloem, meristem tissue at shoot/root tips. Leaf as organ; knowledge limited to epidermis, palisade and spongy mesophyll, xylem and phloem, guard cells and stomata; be able to observe/draw transverse leaf section.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Plant transport: roots, xylem, phloem, transpiration and translocation
Sub_topics.description: Explain adaptations of root hair cells (osmosis for water; active transport for mineral ions), xylem (hollow lignified tubes transporting water/mineral ions in transpiration stream), phloem (transport dissolved sugars; translocation; elongated cells with pores). Role of stomata/guard cells controlling gas exchange and water loss. Explain effects of temperature, humidity, air movement and light intensity on transpiration rate; measure rate via water uptake; use compound measures for transpiration rate; interpret graphs/tables; understand sampling and calculate surface areas/volumes in stomata/transpiration contexts. Detailed phloem structure/mechanism not required.

Explain how diseases caused by viruses, bacteria, protists and fungi are spread in animals and plants (direct contact, water, air). Explain how spread can be reduced/prevented. Pathogens are microorganisms causing infectious disease; bacteria and viruses may reproduce rapidly inside body; bacteria may produce toxins; viruses live/reproduce inside cells causing cell damage.

Measles: viral; fever and red rash; can be fatal with complications; vaccination; spread by inhalation of droplets from coughs/sneezes. HIV: initial flu-like illness; attacks immune cells; late stage AIDS when immune system damaged leading to opportunistic infections/cancers; spread by sexual contact or exchange of body fluids (eg shared needles). Tobacco mosaic virus (TMV): plant virus affecting tomatoes and others; mosaic leaf discolouration reducing photosynthesis and growth.

Salmonella food poisoning: ingested bacteria in food or from unhygienic preparation; poultry vaccinated in UK; symptoms fever, abdominal cramps, vomiting, diarrhoea from bacteria and toxins. Gonorrhoea (STD): thick yellow/green discharge, pain urinating; antibiotic treatment (penicillin formerly effective; resistant strains exist); spread via sexual contact; control by antibiotics and barrier contraception (condoms).

Rose black spot: fungal; purple/black leaf spots; leaves yellow and drop; reduces photosynthesis and growth; spread by wind/water; treated with fungicides and/or removing and destroying affected leaves.
Malaria caused by protist with life cycle including mosquito vector; recurrent fever and can be fatal; control by preventing mosquitoes breeding and using mosquito nets to avoid bites.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Human non-specific defences and immune response
Sub_topics.description: Describe non-specific defence systems: skin, nose, trachea and bronchi, stomach. Explain role of immune system if pathogen enters body. White blood cells defend by phagocytosis, antibody production, antitoxin production.

Explain how vaccination prevents illness in individuals and reduces spread by immunising large proportions of population. Vaccination: small quantities of dead/inactive pathogen stimulate white blood cells to produce antibodies; memory leads to rapid response on reinfection. No need for schedules/side effects details; evaluate global use of vaccination.

Explain use of antibiotics and other medicines: antibiotics (eg penicillin) treat bacterial disease by killing bacteria; specific bacteria require specific antibiotics; antibiotic use reduces deaths but resistant strains are concern; antibiotics do not kill viruses. Painkillers/medicines may treat symptoms but not kill pathogens. Explain difficulty developing drugs that kill viruses without damaging body tissues.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Discovery and development of drugs (testing and trials)
Sub_topics.description: Describe discovery/development of medicines including preclinical and clinical testing. Traditional sources: digitalis (foxgloves), aspirin (willow), penicillin (Fleming from Penicillium mould). Many drugs synthesised by chemists; may start from plant extracts. New drugs tested for toxicity, efficacy, dose: preclinical in lab (cells/tissues/animals); clinical trials on healthy volunteers and patients: start with very low doses; if safe, further trials find optimum dose; double blind trials with placebo. Understand peer review/scrutiny before publication.

Recall and use photosynthesis word/symbol equation: carbon dioxide + water —light→ glucose + oxygen. Recognise symbols CO2, H2O, O2, C6H12O6. Describe photosynthesis as endothermic: energy transferred from environment to chloroplasts by light.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Rate of photosynthesis and limiting factors
Sub_topics.description: Explain effects of temperature, light intensity, CO2 concentration and amount of chlorophyll on photosynthesis rate. Measure and calculate rates; extract/interpret graphs with one limiting factor; plot/draw graphs with appropriate scales; translate between numeric and graphical forms. Higher tier: explain graphs with two/three factors; determine limiting factor; use inverse proportion (inverse square law) for light intensity; understand economics of greenhouse enhancements (heat/light/CO2) and cost-effectiveness using data.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Rate of photosynthesis and limiting factors (Foundation core)
Sub_topics.description: Explain effects of temperature, light intensity, CO2 concentration and amount of chlorophyll on photosynthesis rate. Measure and calculate rates; extract/interpret graphs with one limiting factor; plot/draw graphs with appropriate scales; translate between numeric and graphical forms. Required practical 5: effect of light intensity on photosynthesis rate using aquatic organism (eg pondweed) by measuring oxygen production; control temperature (heat shield/water bath).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Uses of glucose made in photosynthesis
Sub_topics.description: Describe fates of glucose: respiration; converted to insoluble starch for storage; converted to fats/oils for storage; used to produce cellulose for cell walls; used to produce amino acids for protein synthesis. Plants also use nitrate ions absorbed from soil to make amino acids/proteins.

Describe cellular respiration as exothermic and continuously occurring in living cells; energy transferred supplies energy for life processes (biosynthesis, movement, thermoregulation). Compare aerobic vs anaerobic respiration (oxygen requirement, products, relative energy transfer). Aerobic equation: glucose + oxygen → carbon dioxide + water (recognise symbols C6H12O6, O2, CO2, H2O). Anaerobic in muscles: glucose → lactic acid (incomplete oxidation; less energy). Anaerobic in plants/yeast: glucose → ethanol + carbon dioxide; fermentation in yeast used in bread and alcoholic drinks manufacture.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Response to exercise and oxygen debt
Sub_topics.description: During exercise: increased energy demand; heart rate, breathing rate, breath volume increase to deliver oxygenated blood. If insufficient oxygen: anaerobic respiration in muscles → lactic acid build-up; oxygen debt; fatigue. Higher tier: lactic acid transported to liver and converted back to glucose; oxygen debt is extra oxygen needed after exercise to react with accumulated lactic acid and remove it.

During exercise: increased energy demand; heart rate, breathing rate, breath volume increase to deliver oxygenated blood. If insufficient oxygen: anaerobic respiration in muscles → lactic acid build-up; oxygen debt; fatigue (practical investigations may measure effects of exercise).

Define metabolism as sum of all reactions in a cell/body; energy from respiration drives enzyme-controlled metabolic processes synthesising new molecules. Explain importance of sugars, amino acids, fatty acids and glycerol in synthesis/breakdown of carbohydrates, proteins and lipids. Include: glucose → starch/glycogen/cellulose; glycerol + 3 fatty acids → lipid; glucose + nitrate ions → amino acids → proteins; respiration; excess protein breakdown → urea for excretion.

Explain homeostasis as regulation of internal conditions of cells/organisms to maintain optimum conditions in response to internal/external changes; maintains optimum conditions for enzyme action and cell functions. In humans includes control of blood glucose concentration, body temperature and water levels. Control systems may involve nervous or chemical responses and include receptors (detect stimuli), coordination centres (brain, spinal cord, pancreas) and effectors (muscles/glands) producing responses to restore optimum levels.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Human nervous system and reflex arcs
Sub_topics.description: Explain how nervous system structure is adapted to function: receptors → neurones carry electrical impulses → CNS (brain/spinal cord) coordinates responses of effectors (muscles/glands). Use stimulus → receptor → coordinator → effector → response model. Explain reflex arc structures and functions: sensory neurone, synapse, relay neurone, motor neurone; why reflexes are important; reflexes are rapid/automatic and do not involve conscious brain. Extract/interpret data on nervous system; translate reaction time data between numerical and graphical forms. Required practical 6: plan and carry out investigation into effect of a factor on human reaction time.

Describe principles of hormonal coordination/control: glands secrete hormones into bloodstream; hormones carried to target organs; effects slower but longer-lasting than nervous system. Pituitary gland as ‘master gland’ releasing hormones in response to conditions, acting on other glands. Identify locations on body diagrams: pituitary, pancreas, thyroid, adrenal, ovary, testes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Control of blood glucose and diabetes
Sub_topics.description: Blood glucose monitored/controlled by pancreas. If glucose too high: insulin causes glucose uptake by cells; liver/muscle convert excess glucose to glycogen. Type 1 diabetes: pancreas fails to produce sufficient insulin; high blood glucose; treated with insulin injections. Type 2 diabetes: cells do not respond to insulin; treated with carbohydrate-controlled diet and exercise; obesity is risk factor. Compare Type 1 vs Type 2 and treatments. Interpret graphs showing effects of insulin in people with and without diabetes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Glucagon and negative feedback in blood glucose control
Sub_topics.description: If blood glucose too low: pancreas produces glucagon causing glycogen → glucose release into blood. Explain insulin–glucagon interaction in a negative feedback cycle controlling blood glucose concentration.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Hormones in human reproduction and menstrual cycle
Sub_topics.description: During puberty reproductive hormones cause secondary sex characteristics. Oestrogen (ovary): egg maturation begins; ovulation about every 28 days. Testosterone (testes): stimulates sperm production. Menstrual cycle hormones: FSH causes egg maturation; LH stimulates egg release; oestrogen and progesterone maintain uterus lining. Higher tier: explain interactions of FSH, oestrogen, LH, progesterone in cycle control; interpret hormone level graphs through menstrual cycle.

Evaluate hormonal and non-hormonal contraception. Methods: oral contraceptives with hormones inhibit FSH so no egg matures; progesterone injection/implant/skin patch inhibits maturation and release for months/years; barrier methods (condoms, diaphragms) prevent sperm reaching egg; intrauterine devices prevent implantation or release hormone; spermicides kill/disable sperm; abstaining during fertile window; surgical sterilisation (male/female). Recognise decisions involve social/ethical/economic considerations beyond science.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Hormones to treat infertility and IVF
Sub_topics.description: Explain use of hormones to treat infertility: fertility drugs with FSH and LH to stimulate egg maturation and ovulation; IVF: give FSH/LH to mature several eggs; collect eggs; fertilise with sperm in lab; embryos develop; insert one or two early embryos into uterus. Evaluate benefits/limitations: emotionally/physically stressful; low success rates; risk of multiple births to babies and mother; consider social and ethical issues; link to microscopy developments enabling IVF.

Explain roles of adrenaline (from adrenal glands in fear/stress; increases heart rate; boosts delivery of oxygen and glucose to brain/muscles for ‘fight or flight’) and thyroxine (from thyroid; stimulates basal metabolic rate; important for growth/development). Explain thyroxine control by negative feedback; interpret simple negative feedback diagrams.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Sexual vs asexual reproduction; meiosis vs mitosis
Sub_topics.description: Understand meiosis produces non-identical cells; mitosis produces identical cells. Sexual reproduction: fusion of male and female gametes (sperm/egg; pollen/egg); mixing of genetic information creates variation; gametes formed by meiosis. Asexual reproduction: one parent; no gamete fusion; no genetic mixing; offspring are clones; involves mitosis only.

Explain meiosis halves chromosome number in gametes and fertilisation restores full number. Meiosis in reproductive organs: DNA copied; cell divides twice to form four genetically different gametes with single chromosome set. Fertilisation restores normal chromosome number; new cell divides by mitosis; embryo grows and cells differentiate. No requirement for detailed stages of meiosis; may use models of chromosome behaviour.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: DNA structure, genes, proteins and the genome
Sub_topics.description: Describe DNA as polymer of two strands forming double helix; contained in chromosomes. Define gene as section of DNA on a chromosome coding for amino acid sequence to make a specific protein. Define genome as entire genetic material of an organism. Discuss importance of understanding human genome: finding genes linked to disease; understanding/treating inherited disorders; tracing human migration patterns. Recognise developments in science over time and implications for medicine.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Genetic inheritance terminology and single-gene crosses
Sub_topics.description: Explain and use terms: gamete, chromosome, gene, allele, dominant, recessive, homozygous, heterozygous, genotype, phenotype. Some characteristics controlled by single gene with alleles (eg mouse fur colour; human red-green colour blindness). Genotype (alleles) acts at molecular level producing phenotype; dominant expressed with one copy; recessive only expressed with two copies. Most characteristics involve multiple genes interacting. Use probability to predict outcomes of single-gene crosses; use direct proportion and simple ratios for outcomes; complete and interpret Punnett squares and family trees.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Constructing genetic crosses using probability (Punnett squares)
Sub_topics.description: Construct genetic crosses using Punnett square diagrams and use probability theory to make predictions of genotype/phenotype ratios for single-gene inheritance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Inherited disorders and embryo screening ethics
Sub_topics.description: Inherited disorders caused by alleles: polydactyly (dominant allele); cystic fibrosis (recessive allele; disorder of cell membranes). Make informed judgments about economic, social and ethical issues of embryo screening and gene therapy given information; recognise potential to alleviate suffering vs ethical concerns.

Humans have 23 chromosome pairs; 22 pairs for characteristics; one pair determines sex: females XX, males XY. Carry out genetic crosses to show sex inheritance; use direct proportion and simple ratios.

Describe how genome and environment interact to influence phenotype. Variation within a population arises from inherited genes, environmental conditions, or both. Recall extensive genetic variation in populations; all variants arise from mutations: most have no effect, some influence phenotype, very few determine phenotype. Mutations occur continuously; rarely lead to new phenotype; if suited to environmental change can lead to rapid species change.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Evolution by natural selection and speciation
Sub_topics.description: Describe evolution as change in inherited characteristics of a population over time through natural selection; may result in new species. Explain natural selection: variants with phenotypes best suited survive/reproduce. Speciation: two populations become so different they can no longer interbreed to produce fertile offspring. Use theory of evolution by natural selection in explanations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Selective breeding (artificial selection) and inbreeding risk
Sub_topics.description: Explain impact of selective breeding in food plants and domesticated animals: choose parents with desired characteristic; breed; select desired offspring; repeat over generations until characteristic common. Examples: disease resistance in crops; more meat/milk; gentle dogs; large/unusual flowers. Explain risks: inbreeding increases susceptibility to disease/inherited defects; evaluate benefits/risks and ethical issues given information.

Describe genetic engineering as modifying an organism’s genome by introducing a gene from another organism to give desired characteristic. Examples: GM crops resistant to diseases/herbicides/insects, larger yields; GM bacteria producing human insulin. Explain potential benefits/risks and objections: ecological impacts (wild flowers/insects), uncertainty about long-term human health effects. Modern research explores genetic modification for inherited disorders; evaluate evidence and implications.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Main steps of genetic engineering (vectors, enzymes, early-stage transfer)
Sub_topics.description: Describe genetic engineering steps: isolate required gene using enzymes; insert into vector (bacterial plasmid or virus); use vector to insert gene into required cells; transfer at early development stage so organism develops desired characteristics. Interpret information about techniques and make informed judgments about cloning/genetic engineering issues including GM crops.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Evidence for evolution (fossils and antibiotic resistance)
Sub_topics.description: Describe evidence supporting evolution: fossil record and evolution of antibiotic resistance in bacteria. Recognise Darwin’s theory widely accepted; evidence includes genetic inheritance (genes), fossils, and observed development of resistance.

Define fossils as remains of organisms from millions of years ago found in rocks. Explain fossil formation: parts not decayed due to missing decay conditions; minerals replace parts during decay; preserved traces (footprints, burrows, rootlet traces). Explain why early soft-bodied life left few traces; geological activity destroyed many; so origins of life uncertain. Use fossils to infer changes over time; extract/interpret charts/graphs/tables including evolutionary trees.

Define extinction as no remaining individuals of a species. Describe factors contributing to extinction (given context), such as environmental change, new predators/pathogens, competition, catastrophic events, habitat loss, etc (as required by question contexts).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Antibiotic resistance in bacteria (MRSA) and prevention
Sub_topics.description: Explain rapid bacterial evolution due to fast reproduction; mutations create strains; resistant strains survive antibiotics, reproduce and spread; MRSA example. Explain reducing resistance development: avoid inappropriate prescribing (eg viral/non-serious infections), patients complete courses, restrict agricultural antibiotic use. Recognise new antibiotic development is costly/slow and may not keep up.

Describe Linnaean classification: kingdom, phylum, class, order, family, genus, species; binomial naming (genus + species). Use given information to apply system. Describe impact of biology developments (microscopy, biochemical understanding) on classification. Describe Woese three-domain system based on chemical analysis: Archaea, Bacteria, Eukaryota (includes protists, fungi, plants, animals). Interpret evolutionary trees showing relationships using current classification and fossil data.

Describe levels of organisation in an ecosystem from individual → population → community → ecosystem. Define ecosystem as interactions of community (biotic) with non-living environment (abiotic). Explain importance of interdependence and competition: plants compete for light/space/water/mineral ions; animals compete for food/mates/territory; species depend on others for food/shelter/pollination/seed dispersal; removal of a species affects whole community. Define stable community where factors in balance and populations relatively constant. Use observations and interpret charts/graphs/tables about interactions.

Explain how changes in abiotic factors affect communities (with data/context): light intensity, temperature, moisture, soil pH and mineral content, wind intensity/direction, CO2 levels (plants), oxygen levels (aquatic animals). Interpret charts/graphs/tables about abiotic effects.

Explain how changes in biotic factors affect communities (with data/context): availability of food, arrival of new predators, new pathogens, outcompetition leading to insufficient numbers to breed. Interpret charts/graphs/tables about biotic effects.

Explain how organisms are adapted (given information) to live in their natural environment; adaptations may be structural, behavioural or functional. Define extremophiles as organisms living in extreme environments (high temperature/pressure/salt); example: bacteria in deep sea vents.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Food chains, trophic levels, predators and prey; sampling
Sub_topics.description: Explain photosynthetic organisms as producers of biomass; food chains start with producer synthesising molecules (usually green plant/alga making glucose by photosynthesis). Producers eaten by primary consumers, then secondary and tertiary consumers. Define predators and prey; interpret predator-prey cycle graphs in stable communities. Describe ecologists’ methods: transects and quadrats to determine distribution and abundance. Use mean/mode/median and arithmetic mean; plot/draw graphs with appropriate scales. Required practical 7: measure population size of common species; use sampling to investigate effect of factor on distribution (transects/quadrats; measure abiotic factor).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cycling of materials: carbon and water cycles; decomposers
Sub_topics.description: Recall materials cycle through abiotic and biotic components; explain importance of carbon and water cycles. Carbon cycle: returns carbon as CO2 via respiration of organisms and decomposers; used by plants in photosynthesis. Water cycle: evaporation/precipitation provides fresh water before draining to seas. Not required: nitrogen cycle. Explain role of microorganisms in cycling materials: returning carbon to atmosphere as CO2 and mineral ions to soil. Interpret/process diagrams of carbon and water cycles.

Define biodiversity as variety of different species on Earth or within an ecosystem. Explain how high biodiversity increases ecosystem stability by reducing dependence of one species on another and maintaining physical environment. Explain human reliance on biodiversity and how human activities reduce it; describe measures to stop reduction.

Explain how population growth and higher living standards increase resource use and waste. Pollution in water (sewage, fertiliser, toxic chemicals), air (smoke, acidic gases), land (landfill, toxic chemicals). Explain how pollution kills organisms and reduces biodiversity; link to atmospheric pollutants from fuels in chemistry.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Land use, peat bogs and carbon dioxide release
Sub_topics.description: Explain how building, quarrying, farming, dumping waste reduce land for other species. Explain peat bog destruction for compost reduces habitat/biodiversity; decay/burning of peat releases CO2. Evaluate conflicting pressures: cheap compost/food production vs conservation and reducing emissions.

Explain large-scale tropical deforestation causes: land for cattle/rice fields, growing crops for biofuels. Evaluate environmental implications (biodiversity loss, CO2 increase, habitat loss) with given info.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Global warming: biological consequences and evidence quality
Sub_topics.description: Describe biological consequences of global warming. Explain increasing CO2 and methane contribute to global warming. Understand scientific consensus based on systematic reviews of thousands of peer-reviewed publications; explain why evidence may be uncertain/incomplete in complex contexts.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Maintaining biodiversity: conservation strategies and evaluation
Sub_topics.description: Describe positive and negative human interactions in ecosystems and impacts on biodiversity. Describe strategies: breeding programmes for endangered species; protection/regeneration of rare habitats; field margins and hedgerows; reducing deforestation/CO2 emissions; recycling rather than landfill. Evaluate information about methods tackling human impacts; explain conflicting pressures when maintaining biodiversity given information.

Topics.Topic_name: Atomic structure and the periodic table

Sub_topics.description: All substances made of atoms; atom is smallest part of an element that can exist. Elements represented by chemical symbols (eg O, Na); ~100 elements; shown in periodic table. Compounds formed by chemical reactions; reactions form new substances and often involve detectable energy change; compounds contain ≥2 elements chemically combined in fixed proportions; represented by formulae; can only be separated into elements by chemical reactions. Represent reactions using word equations or symbol/formula equations. Exam requirements: use names/symbols of first 20 elements, Groups 1 and 7, and other specified elements; name compounds from formulae/symbol equations; write word equations; write formulae and balanced chemical equations for specified reactions. Higher tier: balanced half equations and ionic equations where appropriate.

Mixture: two or more elements/compounds not chemically combined; chemical properties unchanged. Separation by physical processes: filtration, crystallisation, simple distillation, fractional distillation, chromatography; no new substances formed. Describe/explain/give examples of each; suggest suitable separation/purification methods for mixtures given information; safe apparatus use.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Development of atomic model (electron to nucleus)
Sub_topics.description: Explain that new experimental evidence can change/replace models. Timeline: atoms as indivisible spheres; discovery of electron → plum pudding model (positive sphere with embedded electrons); alpha particle scattering → nuclear model (mass concentrated in charged nucleus) replacing plum pudding; Bohr: electrons orbit nucleus at specific distances; later: nucleus positive charge subdivided into protons; Chadwick evidence for neutrons ~20 years after nucleus accepted. Describe why scattering evidence led to model change and differences between plum pudding and nuclear model. No need for detailed Bohr/Chadwick experiments. Recognise role of peer review/communication in scientific development.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Subatomic particle charges and atomic number
Sub_topics.description: Recall relative charges: proton +1, neutron 0, electron −1. In atoms, electrons = protons; atoms overall neutral. Atomic number = number of protons; all atoms of an element have same protons; different elements have different protons. Use nuclear model to describe atoms.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Size and mass of atoms; isotopes; nuclear notation
Sub_topics.description: Atoms radius ≈ 0.1 nm (1×10^−10 m); nucleus radius <1/10 000 of atom (~1×10^−14 m). Almost all mass in nucleus. Relative masses: proton 1, neutron 1, electron very small. Mass number = protons + neutrons. Isotopes: same element, different neutrons. Represent atoms with mass number and atomic number notation (eg ^23_11Na). Calculate protons, neutrons, electrons in atoms/ions given atomic number and mass number. Use SI units and prefix nano; standard form; relate atomic size scale to physical world objects.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Relative atomic mass from isotopic abundance
Sub_topics.description: Relative atomic mass is weighted average accounting for isotopic abundances. Calculate relative atomic mass from percentage abundances of isotopes.

Electrons occupy lowest available energy levels (shells). Represent electronic structure by numbers (eg sodium 2,8,1) or diagrams; either shells or energy levels accepted. Represent electronic structures of first 20 elements in both forms; link to position in periodic table.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Periodic table: groups, periods and electron structure
Sub_topics.description: Periodic table arranged by atomic (proton) number; columns are groups with similar properties; periodic patterns repeat. Elements in same group have same number of outer-shell electrons giving similar chemical properties. Explain how position relates to electron arrangement and atomic number; predict reactions and relative reactivity from position.

Early tables arranged by atomic weight; incomplete and mis-grouped when strict atomic weight order followed. Mendeleev left gaps for undiscovered elements and sometimes changed order; predicted properties; later discoveries filled gaps; isotopes explain why atomic weight order not always correct. Describe steps and how testing predictions supported new ideas.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Metals vs non-metals and periodic table position
Sub_topics.description: Metals form positive ions; non-metals do not form positive ions. Metals mostly left/bottom; non-metals right/top. Explain differences in physical/chemical properties of metals and non-metals; relate to atomic structure and periodic table position; relate reactions to electron arrangement/atomic number.

Group 0 noble gases unreactive; do not easily form molecules due to stable electron arrangements; eight outer electrons except helium (2). Boiling points increase with increasing relative atomic mass down group. Explain dependence on outer electrons; predict properties from trends.

Group 1 alkali metals have one outer electron and characteristic properties. Describe reactions of first three alkali metals with oxygen, chlorine and water. Reactivity increases down the group. Explain properties based on outer electron; predict trends.

Group 7 halogens have seven outer electrons; similar reactions; non-metals; diatomic molecules. Describe compounds formed when chlorine, bromine, iodine react with metals and non-metals. Down group: relative molecular mass, melting point and boiling point increase; reactivity decreases. More reactive halogen displaces less reactive halogen from aqueous solution of its salt. Explain trends based on outer electrons; predict properties and displacement outcomes.

Topics.Topic_name: Bonding, structure, and the properties of matter

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Types of bonding and electrostatic explanations
Sub_topics.description: Three strong bonds: ionic (oppositely charged ions), covalent (atoms share pairs of electrons), metallic (atoms share delocalised electrons). Ionic bonding in compounds of metals with non-metals; covalent in most non-metal elements and compounds of non-metals; metallic in metals and alloys. Explain bonding in terms of electrostatic forces and electron transfer/sharing/delocalisation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Ionic bonding and ion charges; dot-and-cross diagrams
Sub_topics.description: Electron transfer: metals lose electrons → positive ions; non-metals gain electrons → negative ions. Ions from Group 1/2 metals and Group 6/7 non-metals achieve noble gas configuration. Represent ionic compound formation with dot-and-cross diagrams (eg NaCl). Draw dot-and-cross for compounds of Group 1/2 metals with Group 6/7 non-metals. Deduce ion charges from group number (limited to these groups).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Ionic compounds: giant lattices and formulae from models
Sub_topics.description: Ionic compounds are giant structures (lattices) held by strong electrostatic attractions in all directions (ionic bonding). Recognise/deduce ionic compounds from structure diagrams (dot-cross/ball-and-stick/2D/3D lattice representations); describe limitations of representations; work out empirical formula from a model/diagram showing ions in structure. Structure knowledge required specifically for NaCl only.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Covalent bonding: molecules, polymers and giant covalent; diagrams
Sub_topics.description: Covalent bonds formed by sharing electron pairs; strong bonds. Covalent substances may be small molecules, polymers (very large molecules), or giant covalent structures (diamond, SiO2). Recognise substances from formula/diagrams. Draw dot-and-cross for molecules: H2, Cl2, O2, N2, HCl, H2O, NH3, CH4. Represent covalent bonds as lines for single bonds in molecules, polymer repeating units and parts of giant structures. Describe limitations of dot-cross/ball-and-stick/2D/3D diagrams. Deduce molecular formula from models/diagrams.

Metals: giant structures of atoms in regular arrangement. Outer electrons delocalised and free to move; strong metallic bonds from attraction between positive ions and delocalised electrons. Recognise metallic giant structures from diagrams; use 2D/3D representations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: States of matter and particle model (incl limitations HT)
Sub_topics.description: Three states: solid, liquid, gas; melting/freezing at melting point; boiling/condensing at boiling point. Particle model uses spheres to represent particles; explains changes of state. Energy needed for melting/boiling depends on strength of forces between particles, which depend on bonding/structure; stronger forces → higher mp/bp. Predict states at given temperatures; explain change-of-state temperatures via energy transfers and bonding; recognise atoms do not have bulk properties. Higher tier: explain limitations of simple particle model (no forces, spheres, solid inelastic spheres); apply limitations to changes of state.
Use state symbols (s), (l), (g), (aq) in chemical equations; include appropriate state symbols for reactions in this specification.

Explain properties from lattice structure and strong electrostatic attractions: high melting/boiling points; conduct electricity when molten or dissolved because ions free to move; do not conduct when solid. No detailed structures beyond NaCl required.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Properties of small covalent molecules (intermolecular forces)
Sub_topics.description: Small molecular substances usually gases/liquids with low mp/bp due to weak intermolecular forces; melting/boiling overcomes intermolecular forces not covalent bonds. Intermolecular forces increase with molecule size → higher mp/bp. Do not conduct electricity (no overall charge). Use idea that intermolecular forces are weak compared to covalent bonds to explain bulk properties.

Polymers have very large molecules with strong covalent bonds within molecules and relatively strong intermolecular forces; solids at room temperature. Recognise polymers from bonding/structure diagrams.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Giant covalent structures: diamond, graphite, silicon dioxide
Sub_topics.description: Giant covalent structures are solids with very high melting points because all atoms linked by strong covalent bonds that must be broken to melt/boil. Examples: diamond, graphite (carbon allotropes), silicon dioxide. Recognise giant covalent structures from diagrams; explain properties from bonding/structure.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Metals and alloys: malleability and hardness
Sub_topics.description: Metals have giant structures with strong metallic bonding → generally high mp/bp. Pure metals have layers that slide so can be bent/shaped; often too soft. Alloys are mixtures of metals; harder because different-sized atoms distort layers and prevent sliding. Explain hardness of alloys in terms of structure distortion.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Metals as electrical and thermal conductors
Sub_topics.description: Metals conduct electricity because delocalised electrons carry charge. Metals conduct thermal energy because delocalised electrons transfer energy through structure.
Diamond: each carbon forms four covalent bonds in a giant covalent structure; very hard, very high melting point; does not conduct electricity. Explain these properties from structure/bonding.

Graphite: each carbon forms three covalent bonds forming layers of hexagonal rings; no covalent bonds between layers; one delocalised electron per carbon. Explain properties (soft/slippery, conducts electricity) from layered structure and delocalised electrons; note similarity to metals due to delocalised electrons.

Graphene: single layer of graphite; useful properties for electronics and composites; explain from structure/bonding. Fullerenes: carbon molecules with hollow shapes based on hexagonal rings with some 5/7-member rings; Buckminsterfullerene C60 spherical. Carbon nanotubes: cylindrical fullerenes with very high length:diameter; uses in nanotechnology/electronics/materials. Recognise graphene/fullerenes from diagrams/descriptions; give example uses of fullerenes including nanotubes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Conservation of mass and balancing equations
Sub_topics.description: Law of conservation of mass: no atoms created/destroyed in chemical reactions; mass of products equals mass of reactants. Use this to explain why symbol equations must be balanced in terms of atoms of each element. Understand multipliers before formulae and subscripts within formulae.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Relative formula mass and percentage composition
Sub_topics.description: Calculate relative formula mass (Mr) as sum of relative atomic masses in formula. In balanced equations, sum of Mr of reactants in shown quantities equals sum for products. Calculate percentage by mass of an element in a compound given Mr and relative atomic masses.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Mass changes when gases are involved
Sub_topics.description: Explain apparent mass changes in open systems due to gaseous reactants/products not being accounted for (eg metal + oxygen → oxide increases mass; thermal decomposition of metal carbonates releases CO2 leaving metal oxide). Given balanced equations, explain mass changes using particle model; consider experimental setups (closed vs open).
Recognise every measurement has uncertainty. Represent distribution of results; estimate uncertainty; use range about mean as measure of uncertainty.

Define mole (mol) as amount of substance; mass of 1 mole in grams equals relative formula mass. 1 mol contains Avogadro constant number of particles (6.02×10^23 mol^−1). Apply moles to atoms/molecules/ions/electrons/formulae/equations (eg 1 mol C atoms equals number of molecules in 1 mol CO2). Use significant figures; decimal/standard form; symbols (=, <, <<, >>, >, ∝, ~). Convert between mass and moles using Mr.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Using moles in balanced equations (mass calculations)
Sub_topics.description: Interpret equations in moles (eg Mg + 2HCl → MgCl2 + H2). Calculate masses of substances in a balanced equation; calculate masses of reactants/products from a balanced equation and a given mass of reactant/product; rearrange equations and substitute values with units.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Balancing equations from masses via moles
Sub_topics.description: Balance equations by converting given masses to moles and converting mole ratios to simple whole numbers. Change the subject of equations; substitute numerical values with units.
Define limiting reactant as reactant completely used up limiting amount of product; often use excess of other reactant. Explain effect of limiting quantities on product amounts using moles or masses.

Concentration measured as mass per volume (eg g/dm^3). Calculate mass of solute in given volume with known concentration. Higher tier: explain relationship between solute mass, solution volume and concentration; rearrange concentration equations; use ratios/fractions/percentages.
Metals react with oxygen to form metal oxides; these are oxidation reactions (gain oxygen). Explain oxidation and reduction in terms of gain/loss of oxygen.

Metal reactivity relates to tendency to form positive ions. Metals potassium, sodium, lithium, calcium, magnesium, zinc, iron, copper ordered by reactivity from reactions with water and dilute acids (room temperature only; no steam). Include hydrogen and carbon in series. More reactive metal displaces less reactive metal from compound. Recall/describe reactions (if any) of listed metals with water/dilute acids; place metals in reactivity order; explain link to ion formation; deduce order from experimental results.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Extraction of metals by carbon reduction
Sub_topics.description: Unreactive metals (eg gold) found native; most metals in compounds requiring extraction. Metals less reactive than carbon extracted from oxides by reduction with carbon; reduction is loss of oxygen. Limited to reduction of oxides using carbon. Evaluate extraction processes when given info; identify oxidised/reduced substances by gain/loss of oxygen.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Redox in terms of electrons; ionic/half equations
Sub_topics.description: Define oxidation as loss of electrons and reduction as gain of electrons. Write ionic equations for displacement reactions; identify oxidised/reduced species in symbol equations and half equations.

Acids react with some metals to form salts and hydrogen gas. Reactions limited to magnesium, zinc and iron with hydrochloric and sulfuric acids. Higher tier: explain as redox via electron transfer; identify oxidised/reduced species in equations.

Acids neutralised by alkalis (soluble hydroxides) and bases (insoluble hydroxides/oxides) to form salts + water; metal carbonates form salts + water + CO2. Predict products from reactants. Determine salt from acid (HCl→chlorides; HNO3→nitrates; H2SO4→sulfates) and positive ion in base/alkali/carbonate. Use common ion formulae to deduce salt formulae.

Make soluble salts by reacting acids with insoluble solids (metals, metal oxides/hydroxides/carbonates) until no more reacts; filter off excess; crystallise solution to obtain solid salt; make pure, dry named soluble salts from provided information. Required practical 8: prepare pure dry sample of soluble salt from insoluble oxide/carbonate using heating and evaporation (Bunsen + water bath/electric heater).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: pH scale and neutralisation (H+ and OH−)
Sub_topics.description: Acids produce hydrogen ions H+ in aqueous solutions; alkalis produce hydroxide ions OH−. pH scale 0–14 measures acidity/alkalinity; measured with universal indicator or pH probe. pH 7 neutral; acids <7; alkalis >7. Neutralisation between acid and alkali: H+ + OH− → H2O. Describe using indicators to estimate pH and use pH scale to identify acids/alkalis.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Strong vs weak acids; pH and ion concentration
Sub_topics.description: Strong acids fully ionised; examples: hydrochloric, nitric, sulfuric. Weak acids partially ionised; examples: ethanoic, citric, carbonic. For equal concentration, stronger acid has lower pH. Each 1-unit decrease in pH corresponds to ×10 increase in [H+]. Use/justify terms dilute vs concentrated (amount of substance) and weak vs strong (degree of ionisation). Describe neutrality/relative acidity using [H+] and pH whole numbers; make order-of-magnitude calculations.

When ionic compounds melted or dissolved, ions free to move; liquids/solutions conduct electricity (electrolytes). Passing current causes ions to move to electrodes: cations to cathode (negative), anions to anode (positive); ions discharged producing elements. Higher tier: write and balance half equations for electrode reactions; may complete supplied half equations.
Electrolyse molten binary ionic compounds using inert electrodes: metal produced at cathode, non-metal at anode (eg lead bromide → lead + bromine). Predict products for molten binary ionic compounds.

Electrolysis used to extract metals too reactive for carbon reduction or that react with carbon; requires lots of energy to melt compounds and supply electricity. Aluminium made by electrolysis of molten aluminium oxide in cryolite using carbon anode. Explain why mixture used as electrolyte (lower melting point/increased conductivity) and why positive electrode must be replaced (carbon reacts with oxygen/oxidation).

In aqueous solutions with inert electrodes, discharged ions depend on reactivity. At cathode: hydrogen produced if metal more reactive than hydrogen. At anode: oxygen produced unless halide ions present, then halogen produced. Water breaks down to H+ and OH− which may be discharged. Predict products of electrolysis of aqueous solutions containing a single ionic compound. Required practical 9: investigate electrolysis of aqueous solutions using inert electrodes, developing a hypothesis and recording observations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Half equations at electrodes in electrolysis
Sub_topics.description: At cathode (negative): cations gain electrons (reduction). At anode (positive): anions lose electrons (oxidation). Represent electrode reactions with half equations, eg 2H+ + 2e− → H2; 4OH− → O2 + 2H2O + 4e− (or 4OH− − 4e− → O2 + 2H2O). Complete and balance half equations where appropriate.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Exothermic vs endothermic reactions and uses
Sub_topics.description: Energy conserved in chemical reactions; if energy transferred to surroundings, products have less energy than reactants by transferred amount. Exothermic: transfers energy to surroundings; temperature increases; includes combustion, many oxidation, neutralisation; uses: self-heating cans, hand warmers. Endothermic: takes in energy; temperature decreases; includes thermal decomposition and citric acid + sodium hydrogencarbonate; uses: sports injury cold packs. Distinguish exo/endo from temperature changes; evaluate uses/applications with given info. Limited to temperature change measurement; no ΔH calculations required. Required practical 10: investigate variables affecting temperature changes in reacting solutions (eg acid + metal/carbonate, neutralisation, displacement).

Reactions occur when particles collide with sufficient energy; minimum energy is activation energy. Use reaction profiles (energy level diagrams) to show relative energies of reactants/products, activation energy, and overall energy change; draw simple profiles for exothermic and endothermic reactions with curved line; use profiles to identify exo/endo; explain meaning of activation energy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Bond energies and calculating energy changes
Sub_topics.description: In reactions: energy supplied to break bonds; energy released when bonds form. Calculate energy transferred using supplied bond energies; overall energy change = Σ(bonds broken) − Σ(bonds formed). Exothermic: energy released > energy to break; endothermic: energy to break > energy released.

Topics.Topic_name: The rate and extent of chemical change

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Calculating rates of reaction from data and graphs
Sub_topics.description: Mean rate = quantity of reactant used / time or quantity of product formed / time. Quantity measured by mass (g) or volume (cm^3); units g/s or cm^3/s; Higher tier also mol/s. Calculate mean rate from given quantities and time. Draw and interpret quantity-time graphs; draw tangents and use tangent slope as rate of change; Higher tier calculate gradient of tangent at a specific time.

Recall factors affecting rate: concentration (solutions), pressure (gases), surface area (solids), temperature, catalysts. Required practical 11: investigate effect of concentration on rate using (1) gas volume method and (2) colour change or turbidity method; develop hypothesis; record measurements; evaluate method and uncertainties.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Collision theory and activation energy for rate explanations
Sub_topics.description: Use collision theory: reaction occurs when particles collide with sufficient energy ≥ activation energy. Explain/predict rate changes: increased concentration/pressure/surface area increases collision frequency; higher temperature increases collision frequency and collision energy. Explain effect of solid piece size via surface area:volume ratio. Use simple proportionality reasoning when explaining factor effects.

Catalysts change rate without being used up; different reactions need different catalysts; enzymes are biological catalysts. Catalysts provide alternative pathway with lower activation energy; show on reaction profile (lower Ea). Identify catalysts from their effect and absence from overall equation; explain catalytic action using activation energy; no names needed beyond those specified.
Reversible reactions: products can react to reform reactants; represented with ⇌ (A + B ⇌ C + D). Direction can be changed by changing conditions (eg NH4Cl(s) ⇌ NH3(g) + HCl(g) with heat/cool).

If forward reaction exothermic, reverse is endothermic; same energy transferred. Example: hydrated copper sulfate (blue) ⇌ anhydrous copper sulfate (white) + water (endothermic forward; exothermic reverse).
In closed systems preventing escape, equilibrium reached when forward and reverse reactions occur at same rate; understand as dynamic equilibrium.
At equilibrium, relative amounts depend on conditions. If conditions change, system responds to counteract change; predict qualitative shifts using Le Chatelier’s Principle for given information.

Changing concentration of reactant/product disturbs equilibrium; system shifts until new equilibrium. Increase reactant → more products; decrease product → more reactants react (more products formed). Interpret given data to predict equilibrium shifts due to concentration changes.

If temperature increases: equilibrium shifts to endothermic direction (more products for endothermic forward; fewer products for exothermic forward). If temperature decreases: shifts to exothermic direction. Interpret given data for temperature effects on equilibrium.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Effect of pressure on gaseous equilibria
Sub_topics.description: For gaseous equilibria: increase pressure shifts to side with fewer gas molecules; decrease pressure shifts to side with more gas molecules (as in balanced equation). Interpret given data to predict pressure effects.

Crude oil is finite resource formed from ancient biomass (plankton) buried in mud. Crude oil is mixture of many compounds, mostly hydrocarbons (H and C only). Most are alkanes with general formula C_nH_2n+2. First four alkanes: methane, ethane, propane, butane. Recognise alkanes from displayed/structural formulae and molecular formulae; no need for names beyond first four.

Separate hydrocarbons into fractions by fractional distillation; each fraction has similar number of carbon atoms. Fractions processed into fuels and feedstock for petrochemical industry. Fuels: petrol, diesel, kerosene, heavy fuel oil, LPG. Petrochemicals produce solvents, lubricants, polymers, detergents. Explain fractional distillation in terms of evaporation and condensation; no need for names of other fractions.

Properties depend on molecular size: boiling point, viscosity, flammability; recall trends with increasing molecular size (bp and viscosity increase; flammability decreases). Combustion releases energy; complete combustion produces CO2 and H2O. Write balanced equations for complete combustion of hydrocarbons given formula. Trends limited to bp, viscosity, flammability.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cracking and alkenes; bromine water test
Sub_topics.description: Cracking breaks hydrocarbons into smaller, more useful molecules; methods include catalytic cracking and steam cracking; describe general conditions for each. Products include alkanes and alkenes. Alkenes more reactive; react with bromine water (test): orange/brown bromine water decolourises. High demand for small-molecule fuels; alkenes used to make polymers and other chemicals. Balance cracking equations given reactant/product formulae; explain usefulness of cracking and dependence of modern life on hydrocarbons (fuels, feedstocks).

Pure substance in chemistry: single element or compound not mixed with others; pure substances melt/boil at specific temperatures; mixtures have ranges. Use melting/boiling point data to distinguish pure from impure. Note everyday ‘pure’ may mean unadulterated (eg pure milk).

Formulation: mixture designed as useful product; components have purposes and measured quantities to ensure properties. Examples: fuels, cleaning agents, paints, medicines, alloys, fertilisers, foods. Identify formulations from given information; no need for proprietary component names.

Chromatography separates mixtures and helps identify substances using stationary and mobile phases; separation depends on distribution between phases. Paper chromatography: interpret chromatograms; calculate Rf = (distance moved by substance) / (distance moved by solvent). Rf depends on solvent; pure substance gives single spot in all solvents; mixtures separate into multiple spots. Explain separation; use chromatography to distinguish pure vs impure; determine Rf with appropriate significant figures. Required practical 12: separate coloured substances by paper chromatography and calculate Rf values.
Hydrogen test: burning splint at open end of test tube; hydrogen burns with squeaky pop.
Oxygen test: glowing splint inserted into gas; relights.
Carbon dioxide test: bubble through/shake with limewater (aqueous calcium hydroxide); turns milky/cloudy.
Chlorine test: damp litmus paper bleached turns white.
For ~200 million years atmosphere proportions roughly constant: ~80% nitrogen, ~20% oxygen, small amounts of CO2, water vapour and noble gases. Use ratios/fractions/percentages.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Earth’s early atmosphere theories and evidence limits
Sub_topics.description: Theories about early atmosphere changed over time; evidence limited due to 4.6 billion year timescale. One theory: intense volcanic activity released gases forming early atmosphere and water vapour → oceans; early atmosphere may have resembled Mars/Venus (mainly CO2, little/no O2). Volcanoes produced nitrogen building up and small methane/ammonia. CO2 decreased as oceans formed (CO2 dissolved) and carbonates precipitated forming sediments. Interpret evidence and evaluate theories given information; understand uncertainty and limitations.

Algae and plants produced oxygen by photosynthesis: 6CO2 + 6H2O —light→ C6H12O6 + 6O2. Algae began ~2.7 billion years ago; oxygen then appeared in atmosphere; plants evolved and oxygen increased enabling animals to evolve. Recognise aquatic plants produce oxygen in daylight.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: How carbon dioxide decreased (rocks and fossil fuels)
Sub_topics.description: CO2 decreased by photosynthesis and by formation of sedimentary rocks and fossil fuels containing carbon. Describe main atmospheric changes over time and likely causes; describe/explain formation of limestone deposits and fossil fuels (coal, crude oil, natural gas).

Greenhouse gases maintain Earth temperature: water vapour, CO2, methane. Describe greenhouse effect via interaction of short and long wavelength radiation with matter (absorption and re-emission/infrared trapping).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Human activities increasing greenhouse gases; evaluating evidence
Sub_topics.description: Recall two human activities increasing CO2 and two increasing methane (eg fossil fuel combustion/deforestation for CO2; cattle/rice/pollution/landfill for methane). Evaluate quality of evidence in reports about global climate change; describe uncertainties in evidence base; recognise importance of peer review and communicating results; understand modelling complexity and potential media bias/oversimplification.

Explain that increased average global temperature is major cause of climate change. Describe briefly four potential effects; discuss scale, risk, and environmental implications of global climate change.

Define carbon footprint as total CO2 and other greenhouse gases emitted over full life cycle of product/service/event. Describe actions to reduce emissions of CO2 and methane; give reasons why actions may be limited (economic, social, technological, political constraints).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Pollutants from burning fuels (products of combustion)
Sub_topics.description: Combustion of fuels major pollutant source. Fuels contain C/H and sometimes S. Emissions may include CO2, water vapour, CO, SO2, NOx; also particulates (soot) and unburned hydrocarbons. Describe how CO, soot, SO2 and NOx are produced; predict combustion products given fuel composition and conditions (complete vs incomplete combustion; high temperature in engines forming NOx).

CO is toxic, colourless and odourless. SO2 and NOx cause respiratory problems and acid rain. Particulates cause global dimming and health problems. Describe and explain problems caused by increased pollutant levels.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Resources, sustainable development, finite vs renewable
Sub_topics.description: Humans use Earth’s resources for warmth, shelter, food, transport. Natural resources plus agriculture provide food, timber, clothing, fuels. Finite resources from Earth/oceans/atmosphere processed for energy/materials. Define sustainable development as meeting current needs without compromising future generations. Give examples where natural products are supplemented/replaced by agricultural/synthetic products; distinguish finite vs renewable resources. Extract/interpret resource information from charts/graphs/tables; use orders of magnitude to evaluate data significance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Potable water: treatment, filtration and desalination (required practical)
Sub_topics.description: Potable water is safe to drink: low dissolved salts and microbes; not chemically pure (contains dissolved substances). Treatment depends on water supply/local conditions. UK: choose freshwater source; filter beds; sterilise (chlorine, ozone, UV). If freshwater limited: desalination of salty/sea water by distillation or membrane processes (reverse osmosis); high energy requirement. Distinguish potable vs pure water; describe differences in treating groundwater vs salty water; give reasons for steps. Required practical 13: analyse and purify water from different sources including pH, dissolved solids and distillation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Waste water treatment and comparing sources
Sub_topics.description: Waste water requires treatment: sewage/agricultural remove organic matter and harmful microbes; industrial may also remove harmful chemicals. Sewage treatment: screening and grit removal; sedimentation (sludge + effluent); anaerobic digestion of sludge; aerobic biological treatment of effluent. Comment on relative ease of obtaining potable water from waste, ground and salt water.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Alternative extraction of metals: phytomining and bioleaching
Sub_topics.description: Metal ore resources limited; copper ores becoming scarce. Alternative extraction from low-grade ores: phytomining (plants absorb metal compounds; harvest and burn to ash with metal compounds) and bioleaching (bacteria produce leachate containing metal compounds). Metals obtained from solutions by displacement (eg scrap iron) or electrolysis. Evaluate alternative biological methods given information (cost, yield, environment).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Life cycle assessment (LCA) and objectivity limits
Sub_topics.description: LCA assesses environmental impact over stages: raw material extraction/processing; manufacturing/packaging; use/operation; disposal incl transport/distribution. Some impacts (energy, water, resources, wastes) quantifiable; pollutant effects harder; requires value judgments so not purely objective. Selective/abbreviated LCAs can be misused for predetermined conclusions (eg advertising). Carry out simple comparative LCA for plastic vs paper shopping bags; interpret LCAs given information; use numeric/graphical data and estimates with appropriate significant figures.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Reducing resource use: reduce, reuse, recycle
Sub_topics.description: Explain how reducing use, reusing and recycling reduces demand for limited resources, energy use, waste and environmental impacts. Materials from limited raw materials include metals, glass, building materials, clay ceramics, most plastics; extraction/quarrying/mining has impacts. Examples: reuse glass bottles; recycle glass by crushing/melting; recycle metals by melting/recasting/reforming; separation needs depend on material and required properties; scrap steel can be added to blast furnace iron to reduce ore extraction. Evaluate methods to reduce limited resource use given information.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Energy stores, systems and energy transfers
Sub_topics.description: Define system as object/group of objects; energy stored changes when system changes. Describe changes in energy stores for common situations (projectile upward, moving object hits obstacle, object accelerated by constant force, vehicle slowing, heating water in kettle). Calculate energy changes when system changed by heating, work done by forces, and work done when current flows; use calculations to show redistribution of energy in system on common scale; apply energy conservation in closed systems.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Kinetic, gravitational and elastic potential energy equations
Sub_topics.description: Calculate energy of moving object, stretched spring, and raised object using: Ek = 1/2 m v^2; Ee = 1/2 k e^2 (within limit of proportionality); Ep = m g h (g given). Use correct units (J, kg, m/s, N/m, m, N/kg). Investigate energy transfer from gravitational potential to kinetic (practical context).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Specific heat capacity and thermal energy change (required practical)
Sub_topics.description: Thermal energy change equation: ΔE = m c Δθ; define specific heat capacity as energy required to raise temperature of 1 kg by 1°C. Apply equation to energy changes in heating. Required practical 14: determine specific heat capacity by linking decrease of one energy store (or work done) to temperature increase/thermal energy increase; evaluate uncertainties and errors; use SI units and significant figures.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Power as rate of energy transfer
Sub_topics.description: Define power as rate of energy transfer or work done: P = E/t and P = W/t. Units: watt (W) = joule per second. Give examples comparing devices doing same work in different times; apply equations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Conservation and dissipation of energy; reducing unwanted transfers
Sub_topics.description: Energy can be transferred usefully, stored or dissipated but not created/destroyed. In closed system changes there is no net change in total energy. In all changes some energy dissipated to less useful stores (‘wasted’), often as heating. Explain reducing unwanted transfers (lubrication, thermal insulation). Relate rate of cooling to wall thickness and thermal conductivity (no formal definition required).

Calculate efficiency: efficiency = useful output energy transfer / total input energy transfer; or efficiency = useful power output / total power input. Express as decimal or percentage. Higher tier: describe ways to increase efficiency of intended energy transfer.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Energy resources: renewable vs non-renewable and impacts
Sub_topics.description: Describe main energy resources: fossil fuels (coal, oil, gas), nuclear fuel, bio-fuel, wind, hydro-electricity, geothermal, tides, Sun, waves. Define renewable vs non-renewable; compare uses (transport, electricity generation, heating). Explain reliability differences; describe environmental impacts; explain patterns/trends in resource use. Recognise science identifies issues but solutions constrained by political/social/ethical/economic factors; interpret data with ratios/percentages and graphs.

Use and interpret standard circuit diagram symbols; draw and interpret circuit diagrams for common components (cells, batteries, switches, lamps, resistors, variable resistors, fuses, diodes, LEDs, thermistors, LDRs, ammeters, voltmeters).
