Current is flow of electrical charge; for charge to flow in closed circuit need source of potential difference. Charge flow equation: Q = I t (Q in coulombs C, I in amperes A, t in seconds s). Current has same value at any point in a single closed loop.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Potential difference, current and resistance (V = IR)
Sub_topics.description: Current through component depends on resistance and potential difference. Use equation V = I R (potential difference in volts V). Term ‘potential difference’ used; ‘voltage’ accepted. Required practical 15: use circuit diagrams to set up circuits to investigate resistance factors: wire length at constant temperature; resistors in series and parallel (measure I and V; calculate R).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: I–V characteristics: ohmic conductors and non-ohmic components
Sub_topics.description: Explain that some resistors have constant R (ohmic conductors at constant temperature: I ∝ V; straight-line I–V), while others change with current/temperature/light. Filament lamp: R increases with temperature. Diode: current one direction only; very high reverse resistance. Thermistor: resistance decreases as temperature increases; application eg thermostat. LDR: resistance decreases as light intensity increases; application eg automatic lighting. Design circuits to measure resistance by measuring I and V; draw correct circuit symbols. Use graphs to identify linear vs non-linear components. Required practical 16: investigate I–V characteristics of filament lamp, diode, resistor at constant temperature.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Series and parallel circuits (rules and calculations)
Sub_topics.description: Series: same current through components; supply pd shared; total resistance R_total = R1 + R2 (for two components). Parallel: same pd across components; total current equals sum of branch currents; total resistance less than smallest resistor (no calculation required for parallel equivalent resistance). Construct/check series/parallel circuits; explain qualitatively why series increases R and parallel decreases R. Calculate currents, pds and resistances in dc series circuits; solve using equivalent resistance in series.
Mains electricity is ac. UK domestic supply: ~230 V, 50 Hz. Explain difference between direct and alternating potential difference.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Mains electricity safety: live, neutral, earth and hazards
Sub_topics.description: Three-core cable wiring: live (brown), neutral (blue), earth (green/yellow). Live carries alternating pd; neutral completes circuit; earth is safety wire preventing appliance casing becoming live; earth at 0 V, carries current only in fault; neutral near 0 V. Explain why live wire dangerous even with open switch; dangers of connection between live and earth (electric shock).
Relate power transfer to pd and current: P = V I; and to current and resistance: P = I^2 R. Apply equations to circuit devices; connect to energy transfers over time.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Electrical energy transfer: E = Pt and E = QV
Sub_topics.description: Describe domestic appliances transferring energy from batteries/mains to motors (kinetic) or heaters (thermal). Work done when charge flows. Calculate energy transferred: E = P t and E = Q V (E in joules). Explain relationships between power ratings and changes in stored energy during use.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: National Grid and transformers (incl HT equation)
Sub_topics.description: National Grid links power stations to consumers with cables and transformers. Step-up transformers increase pd for transmission; step-down decreases for domestic use. Explain why high pd transmission is efficient (reduced current for same power, so reduced I^2R losses). Higher tier: use transformer power equation Vp Ip = Vs Is (from equation sheet). Detailed transformer structure not required.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Density equation and particle model explanations (required practical)
Sub_topics.description: Density defined: ρ = m / V (kg/m^3); apply to changes where mass conserved. Use particle model to explain different states of matter and density differences. Recognise/draw diagrams of solids/liquids/gases; explain density differences by particle arrangement. Required practical 17: determine densities of regular solids, irregular solids (displacement), and liquids; measure dimensions with ruler/micrometer/vernier; record with appropriate significant figures.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Changes of state and conservation of mass
Sub_topics.description: Describe that during changes of state (melting, freezing, boiling, evaporating, condensing, sublimating) mass is conserved. Changes of state are physical changes; if reversed, original properties recovered; distinguish from chemical changes.

Internal energy is energy stored by particles in a system; total kinetic + potential energy of all particles (atoms/molecules). Heating increases internal energy, either raising temperature or causing change of state.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Temperature change and specific heat capacity (physics application)
Sub_topics.description: Apply ΔE = m c Δθ to calculate energy changes when temperature changes; temperature increase depends on mass, material, energy input; define specific heat capacity as energy to raise 1 kg by 1°C.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Latent heat and specific latent heat; heating/cooling graphs
Sub_topics.description: Latent heat: energy for change of state; changes internal energy without temperature change. Specific latent heat: energy to change state of 1 kg with no temperature change. Use E = m L (J, kg, J/kg). Distinguish latent heat of fusion vs vaporisation. Interpret heating/cooling graphs including changes of state; distinguish specific heat capacity vs specific latent heat.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Gases: particle motion, temperature and pressure (qualitative)
Sub_topics.description: Gas molecules in constant random motion; temperature relates to average kinetic energy. At constant volume, changing temperature changes pressure. Explain how molecular motion relates to temperature and pressure; explain qualitative relationship between temperature and pressure at constant volume.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Atomic structure, energy levels and EM radiation
Sub_topics.description: Atoms radius ~1×10^−10 m. Structure: positively charged nucleus (protons+neutrons) surrounded by electrons. Nucleus radius <1/10 000 of atom; most mass in nucleus. Electrons in energy levels; electron arrangements can change by absorption/emission of electromagnetic radiation (move to higher/lower energy levels). Recognise standard form quantities.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Atomic number, mass number, isotopes and ions
Sub_topics.description: Electrons = protons in neutral atom. Atomic number = protons; mass number = protons+neutrons. Isotopes: same protons, different neutrons. Represent atoms with conventional notation; atoms become positive ions by losing outer electrons. Relate isotope differences to identities, charges and masses.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Development of atomic model (physics common content)
Sub_topics.description: As in chemistry: evidence changes models; from indivisible spheres to electron discovery and plum pudding; alpha scattering leading to nuclear model; Bohr energy levels; protons; neutrons (Chadwick). Describe why scattering changed model; differences between plum pudding and nuclear model; no detailed Bohr/Chadwick experiments.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Radioactive decay, activity and radiation types
Sub_topics.description: Some nuclei unstable; emit radiation randomly to become more stable (radioactive decay). Activity = rate of decay (Bq). Count-rate = decays detected per second (GM tube). Types: alpha (2p+2n, helium nucleus), beta (electron from nucleus when neutron → proton), gamma (EM radiation from nucleus), neutron. Properties required: penetration through materials, range in air, ionising power. Apply knowledge to uses; evaluate best source for a situation; assess risks.

Use nuclear equations to represent decay; alpha symbol ^4_2He; beta symbol ^0_−1e. Emissions change mass/charge: alpha decreases both; beta increases atomic number by 1 with no mass change; gamma no change. Write balanced equations for single alpha and beta decay by balancing atomic numbers and mass numbers; identification of daughter element not required.

Radioactive decay is random. Define half-life as time for number of nuclei to halve or count-rate/activity to halve. Explain relationship to randomness; determine half-life from given data/graphs. Higher tier: calculate net decline as a ratio after given number of half-lives.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Contamination vs irradiation and safety; peer review
Sub_topics.description: Radioactive contamination: unwanted presence of radioactive atoms; hazard due to decay of contaminant; depends on radiation type. Irradiation: exposing object to radiation; object does not become radioactive. Compare hazards; describe precautions to protect from radioactive sources. Understand importance of publishing and peer review for studies of radiation effects on humans.
Scalar quantities have magnitude only; vector quantities have magnitude and direction; represent vectors by arrows (length = magnitude; direction = direction). Apply to force and motion contexts.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Contact and non-contact forces; interaction pairs
Sub_topics.description: Force is push/pull due to interaction between objects; all forces are contact (friction, air resistance, tension, normal contact) or non-contact (gravitational, electrostatic, magnetic). Force is vector. Describe interaction pairs producing forces on each object and represent as vectors.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Weight, mass and gravitational field strength (W = mg)
Sub_topics.description: Weight is force due to gravity; gravitational field around Earth. Weight depends on gravitational field strength. Calculate weight: W = m g (g given). Weight acts at centre of mass. Weight and mass directly proportional; measure weight with calibrated spring balance/newtonmeter; use proportionality symbol ∝.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Resultant forces and free body diagrams; resolving forces (HT)
Sub_topics.description: Resultant force is single force with same effect as multiple forces; calculate resultant of two colinear forces. Higher tier: use free body diagrams for isolated objects/systems; explain balanced forces (resultant zero); resolve a force into two perpendicular components; use scale vector diagrams to resolve forces, show equilibrium, and find resultant magnitude and direction.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Work done by a force (W = Fs) and energy transfer
Sub_topics.description: Work done when force causes displacement along line of action. Calculate: W = F s (J, N, m). 1 J = 1 N m. Describe energy transfers when work is done; convert between N m and J. Work done against friction increases temperature (dissipated energy).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Forces and elasticity; Hooke’s law and spring energy (required practical)
Sub_topics.description: Forces involved in stretching/bending/compressing; to change shape of stationary object need more than one force. Distinguish elastic vs inelastic deformation. Extension proportional to force up to limit of proportionality: F = k e (also for compression). Explain linear vs non-linear force–extension graphs; calculate spring constant in linear region; interpret investigation data; calculate work done/elastic potential energy stored up to limit using Ee = 1/2 k e^2. Required practical 18: investigate force–extension relationship for a spring; plot graph; determine k and limit of proportionality; evaluate uncertainties.

Distance: scalar how far object moves. Displacement: vector straight-line distance from start to finish with direction. Express displacement with magnitude and direction; use ratios/proportional reasoning for unit conversions and rates in motion topics.

Speed is scalar; often not constant. Typical speeds: walking ~1.5 m/s, running ~3 m/s, cycling ~6 m/s; recall typical values and other transport typical speeds as needed. Speed of sound in air ~330 m/s. Measure distance and time to calculate speed. For constant speed: s = v t. Calculate average speed for non-uniform motion.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Velocity as a vector (HT circular motion concept)
Sub_topics.description: Velocity is speed in a given direction (vector). Explain scalar–vector distinction for displacement/distance and velocity/speed. Higher tier: explain that circular motion can have constant speed but changing velocity due to changing direction.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Distance–time graphs and speed from gradient
Sub_topics.description: Represent motion along straight line with distance–time graphs. Speed equals gradient. Higher tier: for accelerating object, determine speed at a time by drawing tangent and finding gradient. Draw graphs from measurements; interpret slopes; translate between graphical and numerical forms.

Average acceleration: a = Δv / t; slowing down is deceleration; estimate everyday acceleration magnitudes. Acceleration is gradient of velocity–time graph. Higher tier: distance/displacement from area under velocity–time graph; estimate by counting squares. Apply uniform acceleration equation: v^2 − u^2 = 2 a s (given). Free-fall acceleration near Earth ~9.8 m/s^2. Describe terminal velocity: falling object in fluid accelerates then reaches zero resultant force and constant terminal speed.

If resultant force is zero: stationary object stays stationary; moving object continues at same speed and direction (constant velocity). Vehicle at steady speed: resistive forces balance driving force. Velocity changes only if resultant force acts. Apply First Law to uniform motion and changing motion. Higher tier: define inertia as tendency to continue in rest or uniform motion.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Newton’s Second Law (F = ma) and inertial mass (HT)
Sub_topics.description: Acceleration proportional to resultant force and inversely proportional to mass. Use F = m a. Estimate forces/accelerations in road transport; use approximate symbol ~. Higher tier: inertial mass measures difficulty of changing velocity; inertial mass defined as F/a.
Whenever two objects interact, forces they exert on each other are equal and opposite. Apply to equilibrium and interaction examples; identify action–reaction force pairs.

Stopping distance = thinking distance (during reaction time) + braking distance (under braking force). For given braking force, greater speed → greater stopping distance. Use data/context to reason about safety implications.

Reaction times vary (typical 0.2–0.9 s). Reaction time affected by tiredness, drugs, alcohol, distractions. Explain methods to measure reaction time and recall typical results; interpret/evaluate measurements; evaluate effects on thinking distance based on data; consider hazards and risks. Practical context: measure effect of distractions on reaction time.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Factors affecting braking distance (conditions and vehicle)
Sub_topics.description: Braking distance affected by adverse road/weather (wet/icy) and poor vehicle condition (brakes/tyres). Explain factors affecting emergency stopping distances and safety implications; estimate stopping distance changes with speed using proportional reasoning and data/sampling where provided.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Braking forces, work done and deceleration hazards
Sub_topics.description: Braking involves friction doing work reducing kinetic energy; brakes heat up. Higher speed needs greater braking force to stop in same distance; greater braking force gives greater deceleration; large decelerations can overheat brakes and cause loss of control. Explain dangers; Higher tier estimate deceleration forces in typical road scenarios.
Define momentum as p = m v with units kg m/s. Apply to moving objects as a model in collision contexts.

In closed system total momentum before event equals total momentum after; use conservation to describe/explain collisions. Practical context: collisions between trolleys using light gates/data loggers/ticker timers.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: force, mass and acceleration (Newton’s 2nd)
Sub_topics.description: Required practical 19: investigate effect of varying force on acceleration for constant mass and varying mass on acceleration for constant force; measure motion (speed/acceleration) and forces; analyse data (graphs, correlation), evaluate errors and uncertainties; relate to F = ma.

Waves can be transverse or longitudinal. Water ripples are transverse. Longitudinal waves have compressions and rarefactions; sound in air is longitudinal. Describe differences; describe evidence that wave travels but medium (water/air) does not travel overall.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Wave properties and equations; measuring wave speed (required practical)
Sub_topics.description: Describe amplitude (max displacement), wavelength (distance between equivalent points), frequency (waves per second), period T = 1/f. Wave speed is speed of energy transfer. Apply wave equation v = f λ. Identify amplitude and wavelength from diagrams. Describe methods to measure speed of sound in air and ripple speed on water surface. Required practical 20: make observations to judge suitability of apparatus to measure frequency, wavelength and speed in ripple tank and waves in solids; take measurements and record appropriately; communicate method and conclusions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Electromagnetic spectrum types and energy transfer
Sub_topics.description: Electromagnetic (EM) waves are transverse and transfer energy from source to absorber. EM spectrum continuous; all EM waves travel at same speed in vacuum/air. Order long → short wavelength (low → high frequency): radio, microwave, infrared, visible (red to violet), ultraviolet, X-rays, gamma rays. Eyes detect only visible light. Give examples illustrating energy transfer by EM waves.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: EM wave interactions: absorption, transmission, reflection, refraction
Sub_topics.description: Different substances absorb/transmit/refract/reflect EM waves differently depending on wavelength. Refraction due to change in wave speed between media. Construct ray diagrams for refraction at boundary; use wavefront diagrams to explain refraction via speed change. Required practical 21: investigate IR absorbed/radiated by surfaces depending on surface nature (eg colour, matt/shiny); measure temperature changes; evaluate variables and reliability.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Radio production/induction; ionising radiation risks and dose
Sub_topics.description: Higher tier: radio waves produced by oscillations in electrical circuits; when absorbed can induce alternating current of same frequency, inducing oscillations in circuits. Changes in atoms/nuclei produce/absorb EM across wide frequency range; gamma from nucleus changes. UV, X-rays, gamma can harm tissues; risk depends on type and dose; radiation dose in sieverts (Sv), with 1000 mSv = 1 Sv (unit not required to recall). Use data to draw conclusions about risks and consequences. UV causes skin aging and increases skin cancer risk; X-rays and gamma are ionising causing gene mutations and cancer.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Uses of electromagnetic waves and suitability
Sub_topics.description: Applications: radio (TV/radio), microwaves (satellite comms/cooking), infrared (heaters/cooking/IR cameras), visible light (fibre optics), ultraviolet (energy efficient lamps/sun tanning), X-rays/gamma (medical imaging/treatments). Higher tier: give brief explanations why each is suitable (penetration/absorption/energy/frequency considerations).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Magnetic poles; permanent vs induced magnetism
Sub_topics.description: Magnetic poles are where forces strongest. Like poles repel; unlike poles attract; non-contact forces. Permanent magnet produces its own field. Induced magnet becomes magnetised in external field; induced magnetism always causes attraction; magnetism lost quickly when removed. Describe attraction/repulsion and differences between permanent and induced magnets.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Magnetic fields, field lines and Earth’s field
Sub_topics.description: Magnetic field: region where force acts on magnet or magnetic material (iron, steel, cobalt, nickel). Force between magnet and magnetic material is always attraction. Field strength decreases with distance; strongest at poles. Field line direction defined by force on a north pole; lines go N→S. Compass uses small bar magnet; Earth has magnetic field; needle aligns with field. Describe plotting field pattern with compass; draw bar magnet field pattern showing strength/direction variation; explain compass behaviour as evidence Earth’s core is magnetic.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Electromagnetism: fields around currents; solenoids and electromagnets
Sub_topics.description: Current in wire produces magnetic field; strength depends on current and distance. Solenoid increases field strength; field inside solenoid strong and uniform; solenoid field resembles bar magnet. Iron core increases field; electromagnet is solenoid with iron core. Describe demonstrations; draw field patterns for straight wire and solenoid (with direction); explain why solenoid increases effect.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Motor effect and Fleming’s left-hand rule; force equation
Sub_topics.description: Motor effect: conductor carrying current in magnetic field experiences force; magnet and conductor exert equal and opposite forces. Use Fleming’s left-hand rule for relative directions of force, current, field. Recall factors affecting force size. For conductor at right angles: F = B I l (B tesla, I ampere, l metres).
Coil carrying current in magnetic field tends to rotate; basis of electric motor. Explain how forces on coil produce rotation (qualitative).
Required maths skills across Combined Science: 1a recognise/use decimal form; 1b recognise/use standard form; 1c use ratios, fractions, percentages; 1d estimate results of simple calculations.

2a use appropriate significant figures; 2b find arithmetic means; 2c construct/interpret frequency tables/diagrams, bar charts, histograms; 2d sampling principles (biology only); 2e simple probability (biology only); 2f mean/mode/median; 2g scatter diagrams for correlation (biology and physics only); 2h order of magnitude calculations.

3a use symbols =, <, <<, >>, >, ∝, ~; 3b change subject; 3c substitute numerical values into algebraic equations using units (chemistry and physics only); 3d solve simple algebraic equations (biology and physics only).

4a translate between graphical and numerical forms; 4b understand y = mx + c linear relationship; 4c plot two variables; 4d determine slope and intercept of linear graph; 4e tangent slope as rate (chemistry and physics only); 4f area under curve significance by counting squares (physics only).

5a use angular measures in degrees (physics only); 5b visualise/represent 2D and 3D forms including 2D representations of 3D objects (chemistry and physics only); 5c calculate areas of triangles/rectangles, surface areas and volumes of cubes.

Students must have carried out required practical activities and developed apparatus/techniques skills. Biology AT1 measurements (length/area/mass/time/temp/volumes/pH); AT2 heating (Bunsen, water bath/electric heater); AT3 observe/measure biological processes; AT4 safe/ethical use of living organisms; AT5 measure rates (gas production, water uptake, indicator colour change); AT6 sampling in ecosystems (transects/quadrats); AT7 microscopy and labelled biological drawings. Chemistry AT1 measurements (mass/time/temp/volumes); AT2 heating; AT3 conducting/monitoring reactions and pH measurement; AT4 separation/purification (evaporation, filtration, crystallisation, chromatography, distillation); AT5 observations incl temperature change and rate methods; AT6 safe handling/mixing of reagents, exploring chemical changes/products; AT7 electrochemical cells and electrolysis. Physics AT1 measurements (length/area/mass/time/volume/temp; density); AT2 forces and spring extension; AT3 motion/speed/acceleration; AT4 waves and EM interactions; AT5 energy changes/transfers and work; AT6 measure I, V, R and circuit element characteristics; AT7 build/check series/parallel circuits from diagrams.

All students must complete required practical activities 1–21 across biology, chemistry and physics; written exams include ≥15% marks on practical knowledge and working scientifically. Centres must provide practical science statement confirming students completed required practicals and made contemporaneous records. Practical list: (1) microscopy cells with magnification; (2) osmosis in plant tissue vs solution concentration; (3) food tests (Benedict’s, iodine, Biuret, lipids test); (4) pH effect on amylase; (5) light intensity effect on photosynthesis using pondweed; (6) factor affecting human reaction time; (7) ecological sampling population size/distribution vs factor; (8) preparing pure dry soluble salt from insoluble oxide/carbonate; (9) electrolysis of aqueous solutions using inert electrodes; (10) temperature changes in reacting solutions; (11) concentration vs rate using gas volume and colour/turbidity; (12) paper chromatography and Rf; (13) water analysis/purification including distillation; (14) specific heat capacity; (15) resistance factors incl wire length and series/parallel resistors; (16) I–V characteristics; (17) density of solids/liquids; (18) force-extension spring; (19) force/mass vs acceleration; (20) wave measurements in ripple tank/solid; (21) IR absorption/radiation vs surface nature. Students should be able to plan, measure, record, analyse, evaluate and communicate methods and results in exam contexts based on these practicals.
